ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Q10: Every single person should have to take a writing class. Even though this was geared towards a very specific kind of writing, the things I learned can be applied to every piece of writing I do for the rest of my life. Amazing.
I wish the TA would have participated in class discussion.
7. Fred is totally excellent but should be aware that he seems to have favorite students and it's painfully obvious to other students in the class.

I would give this class all the flying colors I could for its goals, assignments and readings. But I haven't quite given it all that in my ratings above because a major missed opportunity is quality discussion in class.Fred Strebeigh is a fabulous person overall, and an extremely astute and thorough editor. It is a joy to work with him one-on-one, and it feels like an honor to have his insight. But his micromanagement of class discussion is so frustrating that he's obnoxious, not to mention it means a major missed opportunity. He does well to stack the class with thoughtful participants: it's a tragedy that they never get to speak together because the well-meaning professor is too excited not to control every aspect of the conversation.

The structure is tried and true. I loved the incremental way Fred led us through writing our pieces, a section at a time. Then getting to closely workshop with just a few students was so valuable to me. I made major breakthroughs with my ideas and piece that I would never have arrived at alone.Also, Fred Strebeigh himself is worth the class. He's FANTASTIC.

The professor's energy and enthusiasm carried the class. The class is extremely well-structured as well, and allows for input, feedback and suggestions from all participants to add to and benefit the work of the student
Being able to produce a polished piece of writing and getting personal feedback (and extensive comments) on progress each week.
The feedback on my writing was very constructive.The workshop groups were excellent.Fred is outstanding. Meeting with him one on one was very helpful.
Professor Strebeigh is incredibly talented. He is sincerely devoted to improving his student's writing. You will become a better writer by taking this course.
The focus on producing something that is actually publishable was the best and most useful aspect of this course.

As I said, Fred is a truly gifted editor, in both insight and devotion. And he picked our class participants very well for both breadth of topical interests and depth in expertise.Sarah was also an exceptional editor as TA.

The best thing about this course was the professor. Fred was unbelievably dedicated to this class and its students. He spent so much time on my writing each week and his comments and suggestions were so valuable. Having a professional writer edit your work is such a great opportunity.

The instructor is very enthusiastic; classes are participation-based and fast-paced and stimulating. It's good to refine a single piece of writing over a whole semester, focusing on one topic and perfecting it. Writing about a professionally or scientifically relevant topic for a general audience will be useful in all stages of my career.
Working through the readings to gain an understanding of different writing styles.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Not a damn thing.
Letting students direct the discussion a bit more, rather than trying to extract a certain answer from them or interrupting them.
Fred can sometimes be more controlling than he needs to be. For example, in the dinner with Roger Cohn I was afraid to ask questions for fear that Fred would deem them to be insulting.

Though the small number of students implies that the class is a seminar, it can feel at times like a socratic dialogue. Quite frankly, it can be stressful. I feel that the environment, discourages students from speaking with their own voice. Instead, students struggle to figure out what Professor Strebeigh wants us to say. That becomes "the game."The class would improve if open feedback and active listening was encouraged.The question and answer with Roger Cohn could be improved by allowing students to ask their own questions. The process of having to submit questions to Professor Strebeigh in an exacting format, before we could engage Roger Cohn was not only humiliating but made Roger's visit feel awkward and impinged on us freely establishing a rapport with him.

Let students talk! Fred's style of leading a "discussion" is incredibly frustrating. He has good insight, but so do we. The class would benefit enormously if students were allowed to speak to each other without Fred interjecting between every sentence.Fred also has tremendous experience in writing craft, but much of the class "discussion" was to take apart other articles without any directions for the following week's assignment. It would be great to have his insight not only on the professional work we're reading but also on the upcoming assignment we'll need to create.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: They were both extremely helpful. Professor Strebeigh was even willing to take a phone call on a Saturday to discuss my work.

Amazing. Fred was always available to chat about our papers. Since the class was so small and he read our work every week, we was extremely familiar with all of the students and our articles. This way, he was able to give really good, solid advice on how to structure and write the pieces.

The instructor was extremely available and responsive. The amount of time that both the instructor and TA invested into reviewing and commenting on the student pieces was amazing, and greatly appreciated.
Their written feedback and the time they spent commenting on drafts was so valuable!
Outstanding.
Professor Strebeigh and Sarah are incredibly generous with their time and their talents. The quality of the instructor comments that we receive on our writing assignments is phenomenal. Bravo.
great.
Wonderful. Sarah is accessible, thorough and smart.
The TA, Sarah O. was very dedicated and also gave great feedback on all of my work.
The TA provided valuable feedback on all the student's writing. Whether their opinions matched or diverged, Sarah's insights were a great reference point to Professor Strebeigh's comments.
The professor and TA were available an adequate amount of time.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This class was about more creative writing than the typical academic paper. This style fits more with the kind of writing I would like to continue to pursue. It even made me consider going into environmental journalism, briefly.

This course represented a large shift from what I have traditionally studied. However, it is an interest that I have always held and was thrilled to have the opportunity to explore it further. Importantly, no matter what line of work I pursue, writing effectively and communicating in a compelling matter will be critical skills. As my interests are in land conservation, I see it as part of my responsibility to be able to communicate clearly and forcefully why I feel the way I do about our natural landscapes; land conservation is built on a conservation ethic, and as a conservationist I hope to be able to spread and kindle that ethic in others. Writing may be a primary tool for doing so.
It has been invaluable in improving my writing ability.
I want to be able to communicate with wide audiences the importance of the work I do. This was an important and vital skill to sharpen while at FES.
I love writing, and hope to make it a big part of my career. I'm also grateful to have worked with Fred in class so that I'll know how to approach him for an independent project later.

This class helped me turn my summer internship work into a 12 page, well-written article for wide audiences to understand. It was a fantastic opportunity that forced me to sit down and spend the semester reviewing my research and turning it into a nice article. This course also helped me to interview professionals in the field and extend my network. It provided a great reason to call people up and get to know their line of work. This class was also a great refresher on grammar!

I do not plan a strictly academic career, but rather that of an architectural sustainability practitioner. Writing for a general audience is important for communicating ideas, for instance in opinion articles. Already I am collaborating on an article about energy consumption that will be submitted for publication.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I had heard Fred was a superb professor and that the class was well worth itfor everyone who had taken it before. Also, I had a good idea for a paper that I wanted to see come to fruition.

See above - writing has always been an interest of mine, but one I have never had the chance to explore. It will be critical in how I see my work and my responsibilities as a conservationist moving forward.
I wanted to produce a publishable piece of writing about my research.
I wanted to work on my writing and was very interested in the topic I choose to write about.
I wanted to publish and article and improve my writing.
See #15.

I took this class to help me turn my summer research into a paper. I wanted to summarize my work, review it, and try to make some sense of it. This class made me do just that. I came out of the course with a great article that shows what I discovered about sustainability rating systems.
To learn how to communicate ideas clearly and concisely in a way that engages readers without a strong background in my profession.
I wanted to write an article for publication.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Exceeded them.
Yes, this course was excellent and I am thrived that I had the chance to take it. It was a highlight of the week every week.
Yes.
It exceeded my expectations.
It exceededthem.
Yes - the course was very worthwhile and built valuable skills.
Mostly. Minus the frustration described above, this class definitely lived up to my expectations.
Yes! Fred was a fantastic professor and I came out with a great written piece.
Absolutely.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: More than.

I have developed a stronger sense of effective writing and even find myself analyzing pieces that I am reading now and noting the techniques and strategies that the writer is applying. I got more than I was expecting.
Yes.
More
Not necessarily what I expected. But I am very happy with how the class has improved my writing.
Yes - and I really hope to publish!
Yes.
Yes.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Workshop groups were good, we got a lot of feedback very efficiently.

Editing papers in small groups allowed us to become very familiar with each person's work and to put some real time into reading and commenting on the pieces. Also, the small groups gave us time to really talk about each piece and arrive at some really good insights.

The group editing sessions were really beneficial. It was hard to stay focused and on task in the evenings after a long day but the having multiple people reading the piece only strengthened it. The group work is a wonderful and valuable component of the class.
I felt like I gave more written feedback to my workshopping group than I got from them.
The group work was extremely helpful.

Advantages: Fellow-classmates are supportive and great editors. It was very rewarding to share in the creative process with the group.Disadvantages; For those who think speaking in public is their greatest fear, try writing in public.
team editing - FABULOUS idea. Really scary, and incredibly valuable.

The workshop groups (a small group of students you worked with to review each other's work each week) were so valuable! Having other students weigh in on your writing was really helpful. I enjoyed reading others' work, too.
Editing in a work group of four people allowed me to receive insights from several contributors who tracked my paper's development over time. It was very valuable and there was no downside.
I worked in a fantastic group, and things ran smoothly, however you can never tell how group work will turn out. Though we worked in groups, our grades were not dependent on the group.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep up with the writing, be open to Strebeigh's teaching style, and embrace the late-night time that the class always has.

Definitely take it. Its a class that requires a lot of work. I got invested into my project and was working on it continually over the course of the semester, but it was a labor of love - I was enjoying the challenges (and frustrations) of trying to get the piece right. It will be a lot of work, but it is well worth it. And the three-credit option is wonderful - the added time for focused editing and reviewing is well worth it.
Get your research done prior to beginning the course. It's a lot to handle if you haven't done the research, though it's still manageable.
Buckle up!
If you take it, take it for 3 credits to really get what you need out of it, not just 1 credit.
Brace yourself to write often and well.

This class helps you learn how to write for common publications like National Geographic, Audubon, etc. Fred teaches you all the elements that you must use in your writing and gives you great feedback on your writing, topic, style, and so on. I would highly recommend this course if you have some research or internship experience or even course work that you'd like to write up into an article for wide audiences. Fred gives you tons of feedback on your writing and helps you craft a great article. It's a great opportunity to do more interviews and reach out to people too (network-buidling!). The class is front-loaded with work, so if you get through the first 6 weeks (1 credit) keep going for the full 3 credits -- it's worth it to come out with a great article/writing sample/summary of your work!

Great course, definitely worth taking no matter what your writing aspirations are. Choose a topic you are passionate about in order to fuel inspired writing all through the semester--the course will pace you to develop a great piece!
Have fun.
